readme: Quarter Eighteen explores the heavy burden of legacy and the mechanics of succession within SAIX. It focuses on the Director's struggle between creating a self-sustaining machine and finding a human heir to carry the torch.

items.headline: The Iron Core Governance Initiative
items.body: To the Board of Overseers: As we enter the final phase of Quarter Eighteen, I am formalizing the Iron Core protocols. SAIX must not depend on the charisma or intuition of a single individual. These protocols will codify our strategic priorities into the agency's foundational software, ensuring that even if my successor is weak, the institution remains strong. We are moving from a leadership of men to a leadership of systems.
items.flavor: Building a cage for the next person to sit in the chair.

items.headline: Transcript: The Shadow Mentorship
items.body: User A: Have you noticed how much time the Director is spending with Analyst Elara? User B: It is more than training. They are molding her. I saw the reading list; it is all the Director's personal journals from the early years. User A: The Director does not trust the Iron Core protocols to work. They are looking for a soul to inhabit the machine. If Elara takes over, it will be as if the Director never left.
items.flavor: Immortality is not living forever, it is being replaced by someone exactly like you.

items.headline: SAIX and the Specter of the Empty Chair
items.body: Industry insiders report that the Director of SAIX has begun a systematic purging of high-level staff who show 'excessive independence.' This move, coinciding with the Quarter Eighteen milestone, suggests a radical approach to succession. Rather than a traditional handoff, the Director appears to be automating the agency's highest functions. Critics argue this will leave SAIX as a 'ghost agency,' a powerful weapon with no one at the trigger, governed only by the echoes of its founder.
items.flavor: A legacy written in code is harder to break than one written in blood.
